You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction following this format:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:
Female,0.0,0,0,0,current,1.4,4.0,150,0
Female,0.0,0,0,0,current,1.4,

heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, diabetes prediction,

The data are then saved to a database and can be used to generate real-time predictive models of diabetes risk and the predicted outcomes.

For a detailed description of the features, statistics, and classification of real-time and artificial datasets, see the relevant section on machine learning and machine learning.

The dataset will be generated by a training process using a set of Python Python classes.

Training is done in the following way:

A random sample of 20 real-time and artificial datasets will be trained using the following python classes:

>>> import random >>> from random import random_sample >>> random_sample = random_sample() >>> random_sample.add_sample(10,20,20) >>> random_sample.add_sample(10,20,20)

The training process is then run with a training set of Python classes:

>>> train = random_sample() >>> train.fit(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20)

The training set consists of a set of Python classes:

>>> train = random_sample() >>> train = random_sample(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20)

The training set consists of a set of Python classes:

>>> train = random_sample() >>> train = random_sample(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20)

The training set consists of a set of Python classes:

>>> train = random_sample() >>> train = random_sample(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20) >>> train.fit(10,20,20)

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status, diabetes_level

gender

age

- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

- Range: 15.0-60.0

- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5

gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2

- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

- Correlates with age and BMI

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

- Range: 15.0-60.0

- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

The data will be uploaded to your project's GitHub page (for a full explanation of what the API is, see here ). The resulting data will be submitted to the project's GitHub repository and will be used to generate the data for your project.

Example:

import MyApp from 'myapp' import MyApp from 'myapp/core' import MyApp from 'myapp/models' import MyApp from 'myapp/core/models' import MyApp from 'myapp/models/hypertension' import MyApp from 'myapp/models/hypertension' import MyApp from 'myapp/models/hypertension/hypertension' import MyApp from 'myapp/models/hypertension' import MyApp from 'myapp/models/hypertension/hypertension/hypertension'

The data will be uploaded to your project's GitHub page (for a full explanation of what the API is, see here ). The resulting data will be submitted to the project's GitHub repository and will be used to generate the data for your project.

Example:

import MyApp from 'myapp' import MyApp from 'myapp/core' import MyApp from 'myapp/models' import MyApp from 'myapp/models/hypertension' import MyApp from 'myapp/models/hypertension' import MyApp from 'myapp/models/hypertension/hypertension' import MyApp from 'myapp/models/hypertension/hypertension'

(c)2014-2013, The Future of Diabetes, by The Future of Diabetes, is provided as a side-note.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi, HbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, HbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, bmi, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, diabetes, bmi, b
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status,

It is also important to remember that the samples in these categories are not representative of the entire population.

If you would like to provide a more accurate representation of the sample size, you can use the following chart:

Sample Size:

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_level, diabetes_predictions

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, hbA1c_level, bmi, HbA1c_level, bmi, HbA1c_level

Then, if the dataset is too large, you can generate a custom record with a fixed weight:

gender, age, diabetes, hbA1c_level, bmi, hbA1c_level, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level, bmi, bmi, hbA1c_level

For example, in this sample of 12-year-old male patients, the BMI is 40.4, so the following table gives an estimate of how much weight you should get for your own weight:

I agree to follow the guidelines of the My Account Policy and Terms of Use.

You are responsible for ensuring that your data is available to me for your own purposes. I agree to follow the guidelines of the My Account Policy and Terms of Use.

If you do not agree with the terms of my account, you may not use my data.

I will not use my data for commercial purposes.

You must provide me with a valid and complete description of the data you use. I will not use my data for commercial purposes.

If you have any questions or concerns, please email me at:

myaccount@gmail.com

I will be happy to help you.

Please send me any questions or concerns you have about my data collection and use.
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi, HbA1c_level

The above features can be found in this sample and they should be useful to people who are developing diabetes in their own homes.

There are also some very important features that could be added or missing from the sample if you are interested in how to generate realistic synthetic data.

The sample includes:

- Age distribution - Age distribution is based on the age of the subject and the age of the participant.

[INST] You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction following this format:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:
Male,11.0,0,0,No Info,27.59,6.6,100,0 [/INST] Male, 53.5, 0, 0, never, 29.2, 5.5, 155, 0

[INST] You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction following this format:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:


These records represent five synthetic patients with various attributes, including gender, age, hypertension status, heart disease status, smoking history, BMI, HbA1c level, blood glucose level, and diabetes status. Some patients have risk factors for diabetes, such as hypertension or a family history of smoking, while others do not. The HbA1c and blood glucose levels provide insight into each patient's current and past blood sugar control, respectively.
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

[INST] You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction following this format:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:


These records represent patients with various ages, genders, smoking histories, BMIs, HbA1c levels, blood glucose levels, and diabetes statuses. The hypertension and heart disease statuses are randomly assigned.
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

age

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

- Range: 15.0-60.0

- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction following this format:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

[INST] You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions:

Features:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:


These records include a mix of genders, ages, BMI values, and diabetes status. Some patients have hypertension or heart disease, while others do not. Smoking history is varied as well. These records should provide a good basis for diabetes prediction research.
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status

Then generate an accurate diagnosis of the condition, based on the data. This data should be generated from a large number of patients.

The diagnosis must be made by using a large number of different diagnoses.

If a record is not accurate enough to give a diagnosis, or if the diagnosis is too difficult to make, it is a good idea to check out the other records.

There are a few other features which should be added to the above database.

Time

If the diagnosis is not yet complete, it should be possible to start it with a short time.

This is useful when you need to make a prediction of the condition with a large number of patients.

Time is an important feature in the diagnosis of a condition, because it gives you a way to predict the probability of a given patient being diagnosed.

The time is also useful when you need to make a prediction of the condition without a patient being diagnosed.

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_history, diabetes_test, HbA1c_level, diabetes_test, HbA1c_level

This is important because when you generate the 20 real data points, you need to generate at least 20 of each of the 20 real data points.

Features:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes,

For the current dataset, only the last line is used.

I will be updating this document with new information in the future.

For the current dataset, only the last line is used.

If you need more information on the data, please email me or ask a question.

[INST] You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions:

Features:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:


These records include a mix of genders, ages, BMI, smoking histories, and medical conditions, as well as both diabetic and non-diabetic patients. The HbA1c and blood glucose levels are varied to reflect different levels of glucose control.
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

[INST] You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions:

Features:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:


These records represent a mix of genders, ages, and health conditions, with some having diabetes and others not. The HbA1c levels and blood glucose levels are within the normal and abnormal ranges for diabetes prediction, respectively.
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

[INST] You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions:

Features:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:


These records include a mix of genders, ages, health conditions, smoking histories, BMIs, HbA1c levels, blood glucose levels, and diabetes statuses to represent a diverse population for diabetes prediction research.
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, Bmi, diabetes, HbA1c_level

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, age

In this case the data is sorted by age and by BMI.

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2

- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

- Range: 15.0-60.0

- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

A few notes:

The more recent you are, the more likely you are to have diabetes.

There are some pretty good links for this sort of data, as in:

http://www.researchgate.net/cgi/content/full/2014/01/28/1

http://www.science.cornell.edu/~zach/chris/

There is a good discussion on the subject in:

http://www.scientificamerican.org/blog/2011/11/how-to-make-your-diabetes-data-work-in-the-scientific/

I don't have a lot of data to add to this list, but I hope you can help me out in any way I can.

I hope this helps.
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi, HbA1c_level, diabetes

This is done to provide a sense of how important each feature is to each individual.

The above feature definitions are for the main features that are used to generate the statistical metadata.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status, bmi, diabetes_status,

The next step is to create a custom dataset for each record. The dataset must be a string of integers, and must contain at least one sentence describing each record. The number of records must be at least equal to the number of records that the dataset contains.

In this case we will be using the following Python script to generate the custom datasets for the dataset.

Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi

The above can be used to generate the relevant data in the database:

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, HbA1c_level

You can also download the complete dataset for your own reference here.

BMI

age, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, HbA1c_level

Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status

Each record must have a unique name. This name should be a list of unique words in the same order.

You can change the name of each record by adding one or more words from the list above.

You can also add a unique value for each record by adding one or more words from the list above.

- Correlates with age and BMI

- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

- Range: 15.0-60.0

- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

NOTE: I'm using the Google Analytics API to create a sample of my data.

gather_data

gather_data_name_file

gather_data_name_file_name

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Usage

You can also use the command-line interface or just use the generated code.

If you want to use the generated code, just create a new file named "craw.csv".

You can then run the generated code using the command-line interface or just use the generated code.

The format of the record is the same as the field, and each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status,

This format is used in the field of this type of data, and is the standard format for field data.

Note that this format is not guaranteed to be correct, but only when it is recommended to avoid the problem of invalid field format errors.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, HbA1c_level

The first line of the record must be a single line with no more than one or two characters:

We use a separate file to create the data. It's called a bmi file. We create a sample file to make the changes to the data. The sample file contains the data for each dataset. The sample file contains the data for each age group.

If you are using a bmi file, you can also use the data from the sample file.

This is a very conservative list. The number of records must be at least 50% above the expected number of observations.

Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi, diabetes, diabetes

You can find the full list of relevant data here.

We recommend using the HbA1c_level and HbA1c_level in your own data sets.

You can also create and export your own custom data sets using the HbA1c_level and HbA1c_level.

The HbA1c_level is a collection of relevant data from a number of sources.

For example, a number of data sources can be derived using the HbA1c_level.

In this case, the HbA1c_level is an abstract collection of data from a number of sources.

You can find the full list of relevant data here.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, diabetes prediction, blood_glucose_level

Note that all data points are valid only if the data point is a single line, with all data points and values being grouped together. The line should only be a single line with a single line, and any data points that are not one-line will be excluded from the analysis.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status

Each record must be an ASCII character (a decimal place-holder).

There is a high probability that you will have a single record that is not represented by the other record.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction following this format:
gender: Patient's gender (Male/Female)
age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)
hypertension: Whether patient has hypertension (0: No, 1: Yes)
heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:

age: Patient's age in years (Float: 0.0-100.0)

heart_disease: Whether patient has heart disease (0: No, 1: Yes)
smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:

You can generate synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction using the following parameters:

* gender: Male or Female
* age: A random number between 18 and 75
* hypertension: A random number between 0 and 1 (i.e., a 50% chance of having hypertension)
* heart_disease: A random number between 0 and 1 (i.e., a 50% chance of having heart disease)
* smoking_history: A random string from the set {"never", "former", "current", "not current"}
* bmi: A random number between 15 and 60
* HbA1c_level: A random number between 4 and 9
* blood_glucose_level: A random number between 70 and 300
* diabetes: A random number between 0 and 1 (i.e., a 50% chance of having diabetes)

You can also generate patient records with different combinations of these parameters to create a diverse dataset.

Please provide the parameters for the patient records you want to generate.

smoking_history: Patient's smoking history (never/former/current/not current)
bmi: Body Mass Index, measure of body fat based on weight and height (Float: 15.0-60.0)
HbA1c_level: Hemoglobin A1c level, measure of average blood sugar over past 3 months (Float: 4.0-9.0)
blood_glucose_level: Current blood glucose level in mg/dL (Integer: 70-300)
diabetes: Whether patient has diabetes (0: No, 1: Yes)

Here are examples of records:

How do you generate these records? Do you use any algorithms or techniques?

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Here are examples of records:

Please generate 1000 records based on the provided features and statistics.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Here are examples of records:

The generated records include a mix of ages, genders, and diabetes statuses. The hypertension and heart disease variables are also included to capture the potential confounding effects of these conditions on diabetes prediction. The BMI and smoking history variables are included to capture potential confounding effects on glucose levels. The HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level variables are included to capture the severity of diabetes.

The data is generated using a combination of statistical distributions and machine learning algorithms to ensure realism and diversity in the generated records. The data is also normalized to ensure that the variables are on the same scale, making it easier to analyze and compare the records.

The generated data can be used for a variety of applications such as developing machine learning models for diabetes prediction, testing the performance of existing models, or generating synthetic data for training and evaluating new models.

blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk

blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes

For example:

Note: The generated records are randomized, but still follow the defined distributions and correlations.
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages
